questions.text: One-year-old child presents with eczematous dermatitis over his face (Image shown). His mother has a history of bronchial asthma. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atopic dermatitis The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Atopic eczema (atopic dermatitis) is a chronic, non-contagious inflammatory skin condition characterized by severe itching, redness, oozing, swollen and cracked skin. Atopic dermatitis: It is classified as an endogenous eczema triggered by exogenous agents.

Highyeild:

ATOPIC DERMATITIS Key diagnostic criteria: Hanfin and Rajka Pruritus- hallmark Rash on face, extensors, or both in infants and young children Lichenification in flexural areas in older children Tendency toward chronic or chronically relapsing dermatitis Personal or family history of atopic disease: asthma, allergic rhinitis, atopic dermatitis Other Common Findings: Skin features: Dryness Ichthyosis Pityriasis alba White dermatographism (white line appears on the skin within 1 minute of being stroked with a blunt instrument) Head-light sign : the periorbital, perioral and perinasal area is spared Ocular features: Dennie-Morgan folds (accentuated lines or grooves below the margin of the lower eyelid) Allergic shiners (darkening beneath the eyes) Conjunctivitis Keratoconus Anterior subcapsular cataracts

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Infantile eczematous dermatitis: It is a non-specific term used to describe any eczematous rash in infants. Option B . Seborrheic dermatitis: It usually presents with erythematous and scaly lesions over the scalp, forehead, nasolabial folds, and ear canals. Option C . Air borne contact dermatitis: It typically involves the exposed parts of the body and may present as erythematous papules, vesicles, and oozing.

questions.text: Erythema multiforme is seen in? Celiac disease ITP Antimalarial drugs Leukemia Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

3, 4 are correct Erythema multiforme is characterized by a target lesion which is caused by either infection on drugs.

Highyeild:

Erythema multiforme: Self-limping cytotoxic dermatitis Cause: Most common cause: Infection - HSV-1, Mycoplasma pneumoniae Drugs: NSAIDs, Antimalarial, sulphonamides Connective tissue diseases: SLE Leukaemia and certain internal malignancy Features: Target lesions with 3 zones Site: Palms and soles Symmetrical Photo aggravation of the lesions often occurs Treatment: Treat the underlying cause, steroids Central zone: Dusky- Papule, vesicle or bulla Intermediate zone: Edematous ring Peripheral: Erythematous border

questions.text: Identify the lesion depicted in the image :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sebaceous cyst The given image is showing a Sebaceous cyst aka Epidermoid cyst. It is a benign cyst derived from the infundibulum or upper portion of a hair follicle , encapsulated in a thin layer of epidermis-like epithelium.

Highyeild:

Sebaceous cyst aka Epidermoid cyst It is a benign cyst derived from the infundibulum or upper portion of a hair follicle, encapsulated in a thin layer of epidermis-like epithelium. Epidermoid cysts are typically filled with keratin and lipid-rich debris Cause: Results from an occluded pilosebaceous unit. Common in young-to-middle-aged adults. Genetic conditions associated with Epidermoid cysts: Gardner syndrome Pachyonychia congenital type 2 Basal cell nevus syndrome. Features: A firm, flesh-colored or yellowish round papule or nodule fixed to the skin surface but typically mobile over deeper layers Diameter 1–3 cm A central punctum Foul-smelling cheesy debris can be expressed from the central punctum. Treatment: Antibiotics, Incision, and Drainage

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Dermoid cyst: It is a benign cutaneous developmental anomaly that arises from the entrapment of ectodermal elements along the lines of embryonic closure. Option C . Cysticercosis: It is a parasitic tissue infection caused by larval cysts of the tapeworm Taenia solium. These larval cysts infect the brain, muscle, or other tissue, and are a major cause of adult-onset seizures. Option D . Meningioma: It is typically a slow-growing tumor that forms from the meninges, the membranous layers surrounding the brain and spinal cord.

questions.text: Identify the disorder depicted in the image below.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Contact leukoderma The given clinical picture shows depigmentation at the site of Bindi which is suggestive of contact leukoderma that is because of the chemical PTBP present in the adhesive of Bindi. Contact leukoderma is the loss of skin color (whitening of the skin) following contact with chemicals known to destroy the skin pigment cells (melanocytes). It is usually due to chemicals found in the workplace, but it can also follow the use of certain cosmetic products.

Highyeild:

Some common chemicals causing leukoderma Chemical Name Industry/Application Hydroquinone Cosmetics, hair dyes, photographic developers Monobenzyl ether of hydroquinone (MBEH) Rubber gloves or footwear, Depigmenting agents like tattoo removal cream Catechol Hair dyes, Black rubber Paratertiary-butyl-phenol formaldehyde Adhesives(Bindi), coatings, textiles Phenol Disinfectants, antiseptics 4-test-Butylphenol formaldehyde Textiles, paper, plastics Thiurams Rubber industry

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Vitiligo: It is a skin condition characterized by the loss of skin pigmentation in certain areas of the body of varied shapes. Option B. Piebaldism : It is a rare genetic condition that causes patches of white skin and hair, typically present at birth. Option C. Albinism : It is a genetic condition that affects the production of melanin, resulting in little or no pigmentation in the skin, hair, and eyes.

questions.text: Velvety hyperpigmentation on the flexural area of an individual suffering from diabetes, as shown in the image. Identify the lesion?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acanthosis nigricans The given clinical picture shows brown to black, poorly defined, velvety hyperpigmentation of the skin in the axils of Acanthosis nigricans.

Highyeild:

Acanthosis Nigricans: Velvety papillomatous overgrowth of the epidermis that presents as dark and thick skin in the flexural areas. Cause: Obesity Diabetes Metabolic syndrome Internal malignancy Drugs: Nicotinic acid, DES, oral corticosteroids Autoimmune diseases: SLE Features: Symmetric, thickened, brown, velvety patches and plaques of skin that appear: Most commonly in the intertriginous areas: axillae, groin, and back of the neck Treat underlying conditions.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Becker's nevus: It is a late-onset epidermal nevus or birthmark characterized by a large brown patch and occurs mostly in males. It is an overgrowth of the epidermis, melanocytes, and hair follicles. It is usually on the shoulders or upper trunk but occasionally found elsewhere. Option C . Lichen planus : It is a condition that can cause swelling and irritation in the skin, hair, nails, and mucous membranes. On the skin, lichen planus usually appears as purplish, itchy, flat bumps that develop over several weeks. Option D . Erythrasma : It is a common skin condition affecting the skin folds under the arms, in the groin and between the toes caused by corynebacterium minutissimum which presents as well-defined pink or brown patches with fine scaling and superficial fissures.

questions.text: Identify the arthropod shown in image.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sarcoptes scabiei var hominis The given image is of an itch mite I.e Sarcoptes scabiei var hominis. The itch mite burrows into the skin and causes scabies . Adult scabies mites are spherical, eyeless mites with four pairs of legs (two pairs in front and two pairs behind). They like warm places, such as skin folds, between the fingers, under fingernails, or around the buttock or breast creases.

Highyeild:

Scabies: Cause: Mite Sarcoptes Scabiei Mites burrow into S.corneum which produces pruritus (worse at night) and serpiginous burrows (between fingers and toes) Incubation period: 3 to 4 weeks e after 21 to 28 days, the person develops pruritis but reinfection provokes immediate symptoms . Female parasites burrow and lays eggs. (1 female = 30 eggs) Life cycle: 4 stages - Egg, larva, nymph, adult Common in children, crowded population Treatment: Permethrin 5% cream and crotamiton ( DOC)- MOA: Inhibition of voltage-gated sodium channels Oral ivermectin Treatment of all close contacts

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Pediculus humanus capitis: Aka head louse, it is an obligate ectoparasite of humans that causes head lice infestation (pediculosis capitis) Option C . Pthirus pubis aka crab louse or pubic louse, is an obligate ectoparasite of humans, feeding exclusively on blood. The crab louse usually is found in the person’s pubic hair, also eyelashes. Option D. Dermatobia hominis: Aka human botfly is one of several species of flies, the larvae of which parasite humans.

questions.text: A Female patient with having a history of fever and oral ulcer, developed erythematous lesions over cheeks associated with photophobia as shown in the image. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

SLE The classic presentation of a triad of fever , joint pain, and rash in a woman of childbearing age should prompt investigation into the diagnosis of SLE. SLE is an autoimmune disorder that can affect multiple organ systems, including the skin.

Highyeild:

Cutaneous manifestation of SLE: Malar rash (Butterfly rash): It is characterized by erythema over the cheeks and nasal bridge (but sparing the nasolabial folds, which is in contrast to the rash of dermatomyositis). It lasts from days to weeks and is occasionally painful or pruritic. Photosensitivity Discoid Lupus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Dermatomyositis : It can also present with skin rash, but it typically affects the muscles as well and may cause weakness or difficulty with movement. Option C . Melasma: It is a skin condition characterized by brown or gray-brown patches on the skin, typically on the face, and is not associated with systemic symptoms. Option D . Rosacea: It is a chronic skin condition that can cause redness, bumps, and visible blood vessels on the face, but it typically does not cause systemic symptoms such as fever or oral ulcers.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple painful blisters on an erythematous base along the dermatome on the trunk as shown in the image. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Herpes Zoster The given clinical picture is of Shingles/ Herpes zoster It occurs in secondary infection with Varicella zoster virus e reactivation of latent varicella zoster from dorsal root ganglion after primary infection- chicken pox Characteristics: Unilateral lesion Dermatomal involvement- most common T3 to L3 spinal segment Mucous membrane within the Derma tome is affected Painful, grouped vesicles over red base Triggers for herpes zoster include Emotional stress Use of medications (immunosuppressants) Acute or chronic illness Exposure to the virus Presence of a malignancy Complication: Post Herpetic neuralgia Treatment: Amitriptyline, pregabalin, gabapentin Antiviral for painful zoster- High dose acyclovir started as early as possible 800 mg 5 times/day for 1 week

Highyeild:

Herpes zoster ophthalmicus: Nerve involved: Frontal branch of ophthalmic nerve (V1) Vesicles present over tip/side of nose = corneal involvement present Herpes zoster oticus: Aka Ramsay hunt syndrome Geniculate ganglion is involved Vesicles over the external auditory canal I/L facial nerve palsy and otalgia present.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Herpes simplex: HSV 1 causes vesicular eruptions above the diaphragm and HSV 2 causes genital herpes. Option C. Molluscum contagiosum: It is a common viral skin infection of childhood that causes localized clusters of umbilicated epidermal papules. Option D. Chicken pox: Characterized by acute fever and blister rash, mainly in children. It is caused by Varicella zoster.
